title: STATS 422 Fall 2025 Syllabus
text:
Proposed Learning Outcomes
The overall goal of this course is to provide students with the foundations necessary for understanding and building on their existing skillset with emphasis on the clear and effective visual communication of data. After this quarter, students will have:

An understanding of different ways to visually represent data (e.g., bar charts, line graphs, scatter plots, heat maps), and when and how to use them effectively to represent different kinds of data and relationships,
An understanding of how to explore and analyze data to discover patterns, trends, insights and then to communicate these to a larger audience,
An understanding of data models: ways of structuring, organizing and transforming different types of data (quantitative, qualitative, spatial) for effective visualization,
An understanding of graphical perception/perceived visual information. Applying some of the cognitive principles related to visual perception and to create compelling visualizations,
The ability to use data visualization tools and supporting software, for example open-source libraries in Python (e.g., Matplotlib, Seaborn) and R (e.g., ggplot2) with , Quarto, and others,
Designing and creating interactive data visualizations that allow users to explore data at their own pace, using tools such as Streamlit (Python) or Shiny (R),
Producing a brief thesis-styled report with visualizations applied in a student’s personal domains of interest such as business, entertainment, healthcare, public policy, and encouraging novel combinations of these (e.g., business + law + data).

text:
Course Materials & Resources
All course related materials are posted to BruinLearn, https://bruinlearn.ucla.edu/courses/217546, all assignments are uploaded to that site as well typically in the form of PDF files, photographs or recordings. Official course grades are found online on myUCLA only. Other materials used:
Text
We will use many sources this quarter, but a reasonable (optional) textbook is:

Healy, Kieran. Data visualization: a practical introduction. Princeton University Press, 2018. https://kieranhealy.org/publications/dataviz/

Software
We will try to strike a balance given the many choices available to us. All of these are free:

R https://www.r-project.org

ggplot2 https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/

Shiny https://shiny.posit.co/r/getstarted/shiny-basics/lesson1/index.html



Python https://www.python.org/

Streamlit https://streamlit.io/



Tableau https://www.tableau.com/academic/students

Optional Sites

A GitHub presence is strongly encouraged but not required. Example: https://github.com/mwaskom (the author and maintainer of Seaborn)
Quarto is useful but not required. https://quarto.org/

Overleaf is useful but not required. https://www.overleaf.com/

O’Reilly library access https://www.oreilly.com/library-access/

A data visualization gallery https://datavizproject.com/ (there are many, make an effort to seek inspiration)
Optional materials

Tufte, Edward R. The visual display of quantitative information. Vol. 2. Cheshire, CT: Graphics press, 2001.
Yau, Nathan. Visualize this: the FlowingData guide to design, visualization, and statistics. John Wiley & Sons, 2011.

Wickham, Hadley. et. al. R for Data Science, 2nd Edition O’Reilly Media, Inc. 2023 and TidyTuesday

title: STATS 422 Fall 2025 Syllabus
text:
Grading
A letter grade is assigned upon the successful completion of this course.
Final Grade Determination
Final grades are assigned according to UCLA’s recommended straight scale grading with minor modifications at the high and low end:

50% and below: F
51.0 - 76.9%: C, 77.0 - 79.9%: C+
80.0 - 82.9%: B-, 83.0 - 86.9%: B, 87.0 - 89.9%: B+
90.0 - 92.9%: A-, 93.0% and up A

I do not assign C-, D+, D, or D-. I also do not assign A+.
Grading Component Weights


30% (9 in person meetings - will drop one, plus 1 recording) Attendance

Being there for the class, this involves attending regularly
Interacting with difficult classmates in small teams during class meetings



30% Three (2 Individual, One Team) Homework Assignments

Web Portfolio (Due before the end of Week 2)
Professional quality report using visualization (Due before the end of Week 4)
Team based “pitch” book presentation (recording) (Due before the end of Week 8)


20% (Individual) Interactive Web App: Find your data, design a website to showcase your skills, make reproducible code available and present it with a video, due by the end of Finals Week
20% (Individual) Final Project: Find your own data, produce a report, make reproducible code available and present it with a video, due by the end of Finals Week
Assignment Late Policy
If you submit your homework assignments before I start the grading, it will not be counted as late even if it past the deadline. Once I begin grading it is counted as late and will not be accepted for full credit (but will still be accepted for partial credit).
The Web App and Final Project should both be submitted before the end of Week 11 (finals week) as grading will begin immediately. I will still accept web apps and projects for partial credit if you miss the deadline.

title: STATS 422 Fall 2025 Syllabus
text:
Academic Dishonesty
As Bruins, we uphold the UCLA Student Code of Conduct. Academic dishonesty means activities like plagiarism, unauthorized material used on exams, unauthorized collaborations etc. According to Senate Regulation A-306, if an instructor encounters a problem, the instructor must report it to the Dean of Students. Sources: https://www.deanofstudents.ucla.edu/Student-Conduct#10690514-student-conduct-code, https://ucla.app.box.com/s/8xq1jyrvqhs9343e4rzyvporx9lt8u1g
AI Assistant policy
Your instructor’s belief is AI such as Claude, ChatGPT, etc. should be used – wisely – as if it were an amazingly clever tutor or friend. But copying and pasting the code of the first example’s (below) ChatGPT response is not about learning and chances are, you will forget how to do it if you do not do it regularly. Asking ChatGPT questions in the second way gives your mind the opportunity to develop the skills scaffolding and retain the knowledge long after this course is over.






Question
Response



Please write some code in R that splits a dataset into test and training.
install.packages(“caret”) # Run only if not already installed



library(caret)



set.seed(123)



train_indices <- createDataPartition(mtcars$mpg, p = 0.7, list = FALSE)



train_data <- mtcars[train_indices, ]



test_data <- mtcars[-train_indices, ]



Let me know if you’d like to stratify the split (e.g., ensure balance on a categorical variable) or save the result to file.


Please teach me on how to write code using base R that splits a dataset into training and test with a 70-30 split - but don’t write the code for me, I want to learn how to think it through on my own.
Absolutely, I’d be glad to guide you on how to approach this! 1. Understanding the Data: - Before you begin, familiarize yourself with the dataset. Use functions like str(), head(), and summary() to understand the structure and contents of your data. 2. Setting a Seed: - To ensure that your results are reproducible, you will want to set a seed using the set.seed() function. This function controls the random number generator in R. 3. Determining the Number of Rows: - You need to know the total number of rows in your dataset to create the splits. The nrow() function can help you determine this.



4. Calculating Split Sizes: - Next, determine how many rows should go into your training and test sets. You’ll want 70% of the data to be in the training set and 30% in the test set. Use arithmetic operations to calculate the respective sizes.



5. Creating a Random Sample of Indices: - To create your training set, you’ll need to randomly select 70% of the indices (row numbers) from your dataset. You can use the sample() function to do this. Remember to use the total number of rows and the size of the training set as parameters in this function.



6. Subsetting the Dataset: - Once you have a vector of random indices, use it to subset your dataset into two parts: one for training and one for testing. In R, you can subset a data frame using square brackets []. You’ll use the vector of random indices to select rows for the training set, and the - operator to select the remaining rows for the test set.



7. Verifying Your Split: - After creating your training and test sets, verify that you’ve split the data correctly. Use the dim() function to check the dimensions of each set and ensure the split ratio is approximately 70-30. You can also use the head() function to quickly view the top rows of each set and ensure they look correct.  Remember to write your code step by step, verifying each part before moving on to the next, to avoid confusion and ensure accuracy. Once you are confident in your understanding of each step, try to write the code on your own. Good luck!



AI assistants are wonderful tools to help you with subjects that are outside of your skill set which do not make sense for you to invest huge amounts of time or resources remembering/learning.

Plan for the Unexpected

Bruin Alert https://oem.ucla.edu/bruinalert

Bruin Safe Online https://bso.ucla.edu/




Question
Response



How will our class meet if we are unable to meet in person?
If we are unable to meet on campus for class, there will be an announcement on BruinLearn about how we will be meeting going forward.


How will instruction be delivered if we are unable to meet in person?
In lieu of in-person meetings, we will hold online meetings using Zoom and post a mix of videos on BruinLearn, covering the content. In order to ensure accountability we will embed quizzes within the videos and require participation for credit if you are unable to attend live online.


How often do I need to log into BruinLearn?
It is expected that you visit the course site daily. If we experience an emergency or if there is another wave of the pandemic, you are expected to participate in the online activities for as long as we are unable to meet on campus.


How will I turn in my homework if we don’t meet in person?
Homework and other assignments will be turned in through the assignments link within BruinLearn. Instructions for submission can be found within the assignment.


How will I see my Grades?
All official grades are posted on MyUCLA. BruinLearn posted grades are subject to change.


If I am ill or cannot attend class for some reason, how can I participate in class?
Please contact me directly for more details if you must be absent or have changing situations so that I can understand how we can best help you.


What if I’m experiencing symptoms, tested positive, or have had contact with a person who has tested positive for COVID-19?
Please stay home and do not return to campus or leave your on-campus residence. Complete a Reporting COVID-19 Diagnosis/Symptom form. The Campus Health Officer will follow up with you for next steps. If applicable, the Campus Health Officer will notify faculty members that the student is prohibited from returning to campus until they are cleared by Health Services. Please review UCLA’s COVID-19 protocols https://covid-19.ucla.edu/ucla-covid-protocols/.


What if I’m having personal problems unrelated to illness? Where can I go for help?
There are resources listed throughout this document and you are also encouraged to speak, privately, with your professor(s), your peers, or other members of the university community during your time of difficulty.
